utterances: I was roughing the past here, obviously.
So I got my penalty.
But OK, this week's question, a very easy one that nobody is going to get.
OK, when Sarah Palin was elected governor of Alaska in 2006, she defeated the incumbent of her own party.
It was Frank Murkowski, OK?
In the primary.
In the primary.
When was the - who was the last woman who defeated an incumbent of her own party en route to winning the governorship?
So if you think that you know...
(Soundbite of laughter)
If you do - you're strange.
If you think you know the last woman to defeat an incumbent of her own party en route to winning the governorship of an American state...
That's correct.
Give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
That's one of the questions that Gwen Ifill will no doubt be asking...
Asking tomorrow night, yes.
And you can also check in on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
We'll take any answers.
I can see hands fleeing up here in the audience at the Newseum.
But anyway, Ken, the economy and the government's bailout plan still the number one issue across the country.
The Senate will vote on the revised plan tonight.
So how come the Senate is expected to pass this with more than 60 votes tonight, and it lost - pretty much the same bill - in the House of Representatives by a dozen votes?
Well, I'll give you 777 reasons, and that was the stock market that went down on Monday.
It was just cataclysmic, and obviously - look, back home, lawmakers are hearing from people saying they don't like this bailout.
Their leaders are saying, the congressional leaders are saying, look, it may not be the nicest thing we have to vote on but it's important.
Banks, credit, things like that.
This is crucial for the economy of the nation.

I think there was a shockwave not only in the - when the House vote went down, but it was interesting, many TV networks had the House vote and the stock market ticker or the Dow ticker at the same time, and it really was really just...
Just one of those roller-coaster drops and the Dow went like 500 points in four minutes.
Absolutely.
But it still didn't make the package anymore palatable for those who are - wavering conservatives didn't like it, liberals didn't like it.
So anyway, the Senate will vote tonight.
The House now said they'll vote on Friday, and they have given sweeteners.
They have some more tax breaks for businesses, they even increased the insurance, you know, amount you have in savings up to $250,000, things like that.
But more importantly, they saw the calamity with the markets and that's why it's expected to pass.
But why did it fail in the first place?
A lot of people are saying, well, first of all, it's a failure of leadership, of the president of United States, the speaker of the House and the minority's leader in the House, that they failed.
Other people are saying, no, this was a prairie fire.
All of these congressmen and women in close races started looking at their emails and said, I can't vote for this.
That's exactly right.
And Democrats probably did have the votes to pass it.
It only failed by, as you say, 12 votes, and like 64 Democrats voted against it.
Could they have peeled off 12 Democrats to vote for it?
Probably, but the Democrats said from the beginning they did not want to be the ones to vote to pass the package because according to them, it's the Republicans' fault.
So the Democrats didn't want to pass the package and then the Republicans could go and campaign against the Democrats and the bailout.
So in other words, the Democrats thought they needed about 80 Republicans to make it look like they had political cover.
Right, and they didn't get that.
The Republicans voted it down, two to one.
But both John McCain, Barack Obama, strongly in favor of it.
You'll see - I expect you will see more than 60 votes passing.
But again, look, who knows?
I mean, nobody saw it going down last Monday.
We have some people who think they know the answer to today's trivia question.
Again, when Sarah Palin was elected governor of Alaska, she defeated the incumbent of her own party, Frank Murkowski, in the primary.
Who was the last woman to defeat an incumbent of her own party en route to winning the governorship?
And let's see if we have some answers here.

Olympia Snowe, governor of Maine.
No.

She was never a governor.
Oh, I thought she was governor.

No.
